title: (x) Mustard Seed Associates, Restoring Eden, CCSP - Papyrus, Adobe Minion, FF DIN {Yves}
content:
Please help to ID fonts her:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121305im_/http:/typophile.com/files/MustardSeedMugs.gif)

Thank you!

 [‹ (x) fat sans serif "Modicoat" logo - Futura {Patricia}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121305/http:/typophile.com/node/19188 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) freeware font used on Jim Sweetwater website - Sneakout {Nicolai} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121305/http:/typophile.com/node/19189 "Go to next forum topic")
author: SergeZuev

comments.content: The rough script-like sans at the top is the — frankly [unavoidable](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121305/http:/www.typophile.com/node/17051) — [Papyrus](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121305/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=ITC.6137.0.0&attributes.sampleSize=24&sampleText=mustard+seed+associates&sampleSize=24).
The classic serif face in the middle is the equally unavoidable [Adobe Garamond](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121305/http:/store.adobe.com/type/browser/F/GARP/F_GARP-10005000.html).

The tech sans at the bottom is the equally unavoidable [DIN 1451 Mittelschrift](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121305/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=LH.107934.0.3&attributes.sampleSize=32&sampleText=ccsp&sampleSize=48). The presence of [different weights](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121305/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=FF.9467.11.1&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=creation+care+study+program&sampleSize=16) tells us it’s [Albert-Jan Pool](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121305/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Albert-Jan%252BPool)’s upgraded digitisation for [FontFont](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121305/http:/typophile.com/wiki/FontFont).
I had some catching up to do... :^D
Actually, the second one looks more like [Minion](http://web.archive.org/) — see the R and G. The bitmapping makes it difficult to see the finer details.
